bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, January 8, 1944

div1.p: Kean describes Hench's visit to his house and admits that his memory is fading.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, January 8, 1944

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
Jan 8/44

div1.p:
Your brave and cheerful
letter written on Dec. 26 made
me very happy and gave a
good start to the New Year. It
is perfectly fine the way you have
recovered from what you very
properly call your cerebral accident
and with your charming wife and
your daughters and grand daughter
around you to wait on you and
spoil you, you will want never to get
quite well- Col. Hench has been in
to see me several times- He arri-
ved a week ago with a huge box of
Walter Reeds letters including his
2
his love letters to Mrs Reed when he
was courting her, and the biggest scrap
book I ever saw- These he had
borrowed from Mrs Reed and
Blossom when he stopped by
Blue Ridge Summit to see them
when he came last- I glanced over
the scrap book but did not tackle
the bundles of domestic correspondence
He came in on Thursday 6th at 7 p m
with Mrs Franck from the Office of the
Military Surgeons as stenog, to try to extract
a few last details from my fading
memories of 43 years ago- He wants
to get some light on when Reed first
began to consider seriously the mosqui-
to theory- Whether he did so before he
3
came to Cuba with the Y. F. Board
on June 25th- I cannot give him any
light on that point as I was sick
with y. f. when he arrived and went
off on leave as soon as I was able
to travel and when I returned to
Cuba on Aug, 20 he was in Washington
So I did not have any talk with
him on that subject until the decisions
had been reached to try out the Finlay
theory- I have suggested to him to
write to Dr. L. O. Howard with whom he
talked mosquitoes before he left Washing-
ton in June- Dr. Howard is now in
New York and I think has failed
a good deal mentally but he maybe
able to recall something of value-
4
He wanted me to describe in detail
Lazear's funeral, but we had quite
a number of funerals about that time and they are
much confused and vague in my
recollections- Gen. Lee & his staff went
to there mounted, as the dear old fellow
much preferred to sit on a horse to
standing & walking on his short sturdy
legs, and the horse rather was a division
to his feelings- At least that is my
idea of the psychology of his ordering his
horse to go half a mile-

Well old man give my love to all your
girls. I hope you will all be as happy
all the year as I believe you to be
at present-
